photo.description: This was one of the great parts of the Atomium, travelling through the supporting structures between the spheres. They had little portholes so you got glimpses of the sky and sometimes odd views of the structure but it was a surreal experience to be moved through this metal tube. I liked how it leant itself to a vanishing point photo so tried to take advantage of that and have a very centred shot. Ideally I would have been at the bottom of the escalator where it was a bit more steady but people kept wanting to go up and I thought it would be much better without people in the shot so had to eventually get on otherwise I would never get the shot. I tried a different angle for Into Another World which in my mind became a much stronger photo because I wasn't able to keep this shot as steady due to the vibrations of the escalator.

photo.title: To The Future From The Past - Atomium, Brussels

photo.description: The Atomium is a monument in Brussels, originally built for Expo '58, the 1958 Brussels World's Fair. Designed by André Waterkeyn and Les Architectes Polak, it stands 102 metres (335 ft) tall. It has nine steel spheres connected so that the whole forms the shape of a unit cell of an iron crystal magnified 165 billion times. N.B.Het beeld van het Atomium beschermd is en het gebruik ervan onderworpen is aan voorwaarden, zie:http://atomium.be/?lang=nl#/AuthorsRights.aspx?lang=nl © www.atomium.be - SABAM 2012 - HDR-newaddict

photo.title: Light In A Dark Place - Atomium, Brussels

photo.description: #216 Explore @ 2007 09 24 Built for the 1958 Brussels World's Fair (Expo '58), the 103-metre (335-foot) tall Atomium monument represents a unit cell of an iron crystal (body-centred cubic), magnified 165 billion times, with vertical body diagonal, with tubes along the 12 edges of the cube and from all 8 vertices to the centre. Nine steel spheres 18 metres in diameter connect via tubes with escalators as long as 35 m, among the longest in Europe. Windows in the top sphere provide a panoramic view of Brussels. Other spheres have 1950s exhibitions. Three upper spheres lacking vertical support are not open to the public for safety reasons. Planned originally to last only six months, architect André Waterkeyn's design has survived to become a popular tourist attraction that some feel is a Belgian national icon rivalling Manneken Pis Renovation Beginning in March 2004, much-needed renovation work has included replacing faded aluminium sheets on the balls with stainless steel. To help pay for renovations, the old aluminium has been sold to the public as souvenirs. A triangular piece about 2 m long sold for €1,000. The Atomium, which had been closed to the public since October 2004, re-opened on 18th February 2006. The renovation includes revamped exhibition spaces, a restaurant, and an overnight dormitory called Kids Sphere Hotel for visiting schoolchildren. The dormitory features suspended plastic sphere towers. (Keep reading at the Wikipedia) ------- El Atomium es una estructura de 103 metros de altura construida para la Exposición General de primera categoría de Bruselas de 1958. Representa un cristal de hierro ampliado 165 mil millones de veces. Está formado por nueve esferas de acero de 18 metros de diámetro. La estructura, diseñada por el arquitecto André Waterkeyn, fue planeada para permanecer seis meses; sin embargo rápidamente se convirtió en una atracción turística. A partir de marzo de 2004, se llevó a cabo un proceso de renovación. El Atomium abrió nuevamente, totalmente renovado, el 18 de febrero de 2006. En su interior se incluyó un elevador que lleva a la cima a una velocidad de 5 m/s.

photo.title: Atomium

photo.description: I really liked the Atomium and the complex structure that it is comprised of. It gave me multiple opportunities to get interesting shots, playing with the spheres and the supporting tubes. I spent quite a while outside trying to get different angles and new perspectives. I have several of my attempts through my Photostream. I wish that it had been a bit better weather and had blue skies as the background, but it seemed to work better for when I did black and white shots so I think it was okay in the end.

photo.description: The House : one of the miniatures of Mini-Europe, an amusement park, displaying miniature monuments and buildings from Europe. The Atomium : a unit cell of an iron crystal magnified 165 billion times. It was built for the 1958 Universal Exhibition in Brussels and is since one of the main attractions of the city. ............................................. La (mini) maison et l'atome (géant) La maison : une des miniatures du parc d'attraction "Mini Europe", qui propose aux visiteurs des reproductions réduites des principaux monuments européens. L'Atomium : une molécule de fer, agrandie des milliers de fois. Il fut construit pour l'Expo 58, l'Exposition Universelle à Bruxelles. Il est depuis une des attractions majeures de la ville.

photo.description: "Built for the 1958 Brussels World's Fair (Expo '58), the 103-meter (335-foot) tall Atomium monument represents a unit cell of an iron crystal (body-centered cubic), magnified 165 billion times, with vertical body diagonal, with tubes along the 12 edges of the cube and from all 8 vertices to the center. Nine steel spheres 18 meters in diameter connect via tubes with escalators as long as 35 m, among the longest in Europe. Windows in the top sphere provide a panoramic view of Brussels. Other spheres have 1950s exhibitions. Three upper spheres lacking vertical support are not open to the public for safety reasons." From: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomium -- 11 May 2006
photo.tags: atomium brussel brussels bruxelles expo58 heizel heyzel fifties architecture
photo.title: Atomium, detail

photo.description: Atomium, Brussel [?] Het Atomium staat voor de Wereldtentoonstelling in Brussel in 1958, de zogenaamde Expo 58, als symbool voor het metaal “ijzer“ dat sterk in ontwikkeling was en een belangrijke rol speelde in de optimistische kijk op ontwikkeling in de jaren vijftig. Het heeft de kubisch ruimtelijk gecentreerde structuur, niet de kubisch vlakgecentreerde zoals in zuiver ijzer. Vreemd genoeg werd bij de bouw besloten dat de bollen niet van staal, maar van aluminium moesten worden gemaakt. Dit materiaal was indertijd ook een materiaal in opkomst. Het is niet precies bekend waarom dit besluit werd genomen, maar het zal ermee te maken gehad hebben, dat aluminium op dat ogenblik aanmerkelijk beter bestand was tegen corrosie dan staal. Het gebouw zou volgens plan niet langer dan zes maanden blijven staan. Aan het eind van de wereldtentoonstelling werd echter besloten om het gebouw, dat enorm populair en bekend was geworden, toch maar te laten staan. Het betreft een stalen constructie die bestaat uit negen bollen met elk een diameter van 18 meter, die allemaal precies 29 meter van elkaar afstaan, en samen de kubisch ruimtelijk gecentreerde kristalstructuur van ijzer uitbeelden, 165 miljard maal vergroot. Het gebouw, dat ontworpen is door architect André Waterkeyn, is, sinds de restauratie, bekleed met roestvrij staal (oorspronkelijk aluminium). De aluminium constructie woog destijds in lege staat 2500 ton. De bovenste bol van het Atomium werd naar zijn ontwerper André Waterkeyn genoemd, na diens dood in 2005. De totale hoogte van het monument, de diagonaal van de kubus, is 102,705 meter. Het grondvlak is een zeshoek met een diagonaal van 94,75 meter. De negen bollen, die een diameter van 18 meter hebben, bestaan elk uit 48 driehoekige platen van 2 mm dik. Voor de restauratie waren er 720 platen per bol. De bollen zijn met elkaar verbonden door middel van roltrappen en gewone trappen. De drie buitenste hoge bollen hebben geen verticale dragers en zijn om veiligheidsredenen gesloten voor publiek. Er zijn 5 bollen toegankelijk voor het publiek: Met de lift kan men naar de bovenste bol waar men kan genieten van een prachtig uitzicht over de stad en een restaurant. Met de roltrappen en gewone trappen bereikt men: * de basisbol, waar een permanente tentoonstelling over "Expo 58: de tentoonstelling" en de jaren 50 is tentoongesteld; * de tentoonstellingsbol met tijdelijke tentoonstellingen; * de centrale bol, waar een snackbar is ondergebracht; * de kinderbol (let wel op: deze is niet toegankelijk voor het publiek - enkel voor schoolgroepen die er in overnachten). * Elke bol, die een "sphere" wordt genoemd, heeft een oppervlakte van 1082 m² en elk niveau heeft een oppervlakte van 240 m² (er zijn steeds twee niveaus per sphere). De Sphere Waterkeyn (dit is de bovenste bol) heeft drie niveaus. * De lift heeft een snelheid van 5 meter per seconde. * Er zijn 20 "verbindingsbuizen" tussen de bollen. Een verbindingsbuis heeft een diameter van 3 m en een lengte van 23 m of 18 m. * De "bipode" is de ondersteuning voor de onderste bollen. Deze heeft een hoogte van 35 m en telt 200 treden.

photo.description: Brussels, Belgium Das Atomium ist ein Wahrzeichen Brüssels. Es wurde zur Weltausstellung 1958 von dem Architekten André Waterkeyn als Symbol für das Atomzeitalter und die friedliche Nutzung der Kernenergie entworfen und unter Leitung der Architekten André und Michel Polak errichtet. Es stellt mit Hilfe von neun Atomen die kubisch-raumzentrierte Elementarzelle einer Eisen-Kristallstruktur in 165-Milliarden-facher Vergrößerung dar. (wikipedia) See where this picture was taken. [?]

photo.title: Euphorie in Stahl

photo.description: This was one of the great parts of the Atomium, travelling through the supporting structures between the spheres. They had little portholes so you got glimpses of the sky and sometimes odd views of the structure but it was a surreal experience to be moved through this metal tube. I liked how it leant itself to a vanishing point photo so tried to take advantage of that and have a very centred shot. Ideally I would have been at the bottom of the escalator where it was a bit more steady but people kept wanting to go up and I thought it would be much better without people in the shot so had to eventually get on otherwise I would never get the shot. I tried a different angle by kneeling down in To The Future From The Past which I really liked because of the reflections on the sides of the escalator but it didn't end up as clear as this shot did and I thought this was much more powerful.

photo.description: Once upon a time, there was a united country. And the symbol of this unity. Decades later, this unity is in danger and there is like an eclipse on what was once a symbol and could become only a memorial. Il était une fois un pays uni et le symbole de cet unité. Des décennies plus tard, l'unité tombe en pièces et il y a comme une éclipse sur ce qui fut un symbole et ne pourrait plus être qu'un mémorial. Atomium, Belgium View On Black The Sound of the Atom Splitting (Pet Shop Boys)

photo.title: Das Atomium

photo.description: È una costruzione in acciaio, consistente di 9 sfere che rappresentano un cristallo di ferro ingrandito 165 miliardi di volte. Venne costruito in occasione dell'Expo del 1958. Progettato dall'architetto André Waterkeyn, in origine doveva durare 6 mesi. Il monumento ha un'altezza totale di 103 metri. Le sfere, che hanno un diametro di 18 metri, sono collegate da scale mobili e da scale dalle quali, tramite finestrature ed oblò, è possibile guardare le altre sfere o il panorama sottostante. Tre delle sfere superiori non hanno supporto verticale e quindi, per motivi di sicurezza, non sono aperte al pubblico. Dalle finestre della sfera superiore si può godere di una vista panoramica di Bruxelles, mentre le altre sfere ospitano diverse mostre (wikipedia it). ha il suo perché, mi piace

photo.title: Atomium, Brussels (closer detail)

photo.description: Built in Brussels, Belgium, for the World Fair, 1958. An extraordinary building. Actually, it isn't a building at all. It is building sized, but it is really a 'copyrighted work of art'. Not my photo- the structure itself. For example- Wikimedia Commons says [sic]: 'Do not upload images of the Atomium in Brussels. This building is copyrighted artwork. Nobody is allowed distributing his own photos of the Atomium without the consent of the copyright holders in Belgium and other countries without the Freedom of Panorama. So all Atomium images will get deleted in Commons on sight. Thank you for your cooperation. (See the talk page for more information)' and 'The image of the Atomium is protected since its construction. It's mandatory to gain approval from the vzw/asbl Atomium and the SABAM, before copying or broadcasting the image of the Atomium. It is also necessary to mention "copyright vzw/asbl Atomium".' Nevertheless- do a flickr or a google search for 'Atomium' and you'll find thousands of pictures of it. I suppose it's like the Coca-Cola or the London Underground logos- take pictures of them but don't try and make money out of it. I guess the city of Brussels is just trying to protect its lucrative t-shirt, postcard and assorted tchotchke market. After all , the iconic Mannekin Pis is long out of copyright.
photo.tags: agat18 film agathack august2010 atomium brussels belomo lomo belarus cccp ussr sovietcamera

photo.title: Mini-Europe

photo.description: Walking away from the Atomium, I wanted to try and take advantage of the symmetry in this giant structure. I walked up the grass and kept stopping to take the photo only to find that it didn't quite fit and so kept having to move and retake the photo. Finally I found a point where it was all centred and took my shot. I thought I would give a little tribute to the photos inside of the Atomium of the building for the '58 Expo when the photos were only Black and White or sepia. I really like the end result and like how the clouds seemed to naturally illuminate the structure.
